questions.question: 1.How would you differentiate a colloid mixture from a solution?

answers.c: A colloid has a positive charge.
answers.d: A colloid has a negative charge.

explanations.a: a colloidal solution has larger sized particles dispersed in solvent which can be seen using the tyndall effect too.
explanations.b: solution has smaller particles than colloids. A solution does not show a tyndall effect.
explanations.c: charges do not play a key role in differentiating colloid and solution.
explanations.d: irrespective of positive or negative charge, charges do not affect the differentiation between colloid and solution.

questions.question: 2. What technique can be used to distinguish between a suspension and a colloid?

answers.a: By shaking and watching for separation.
answers.b: By heating the mixture to boiling.
answers.c: By freezing the mixture to a solid state.

explanations.a: shaking the mixture and letting it settle can separate a suspension from colloid. The particles in suspension separate out while in colloids it does not.
explanations.b: heating the mixture will increase the solubility of the solvent in both cases to some extent but will not help in separation.
explanations.c: freezing will not help as the particles will freeze in suspended state in both the mixtures.

questions.question: 3. How will the gel property change if the concentration of buffer solution is increased?

answers.b: the strength of the agar agar gel decreases.
answers.c: pore size increases in agar agar gel.

explanations.a: stability of gel depends on degree of hydration and charge.
explanations.b: strength depends on pH, sugar content, rate of gelation.
explanations.c: interstitial pore size depends strongly on the ionic strength, which in turn is moderated by buffer. With increase in buffer concentration and lower agarose concentration, pore size increases.
explanations.d: increasing the quantity of sugar gives harder gels.

questions.question: 4. Agar is known to have a high hysteresis due to which it has the following benefits:

answers.a: it is remarkably stable only at low temperatures.
answers.b: it is stable in a wide range of temperatures.
answers.c: It is highly stable in higher temperatures.
answers.d: does not solidify easily and needs refrigeration.

explanations.a: hysteresis is the difference between the gelling and melting temperatures of a gel. Agar has a gelling temperature of 34-38 C and melts if heated to 85-90 C. hence it is not so stable in lower temperatures.
explanations.b: having a large hysteresis is indicative of a wide stable range.
explanations.c: only upto its melting temperature of 85-90 C , agar is stable beyond which its nature starts degrading.
explanations.d: agar solidifies easily and does not need refrigeration.
